title: Ticket #1167: GSI leaks memory
description:
We have several pieces of evidence that GSI authentication leaks memory. I found one leak that goes back to at least 7.1.4, probably earlier. There is another leak in the new VOMS stuff, first released in 7.3.2.

Evidence:

I took a look at one of the glidein 7.4.1 sub-collectors at UCSD. By analyzing strings in the core file, it is pretty obvious that there is a memory leak related to GSI or VOMS. There are less than a hundred security sessions and ads in the collector, but the count of how many times the same string appears in the core file comes up with some fairly big numbers: 

 14427 lcg-voms.cern.ch0
 15590 DOEGrids
 15593 DOEGrids1 0
 15849     computers1
 16020 cern1
 17004 proxy
 23306 ESnet
 23568 ESnet1 0
 23605 net1
 24614 ]MH/
 25517 doegrids
 25524 Services
 27071 DOEGrids CA 1
 34215 Services1+0)
 34325 doegrids1
 38820 Certificate Authorities
 39241 Certificate Authorities1
 40049 ESnet Root CA 1
 51072 org1

A google heap profiler dump from a 7.4.1 condor_collector from glideinWMS in Nebraska showed that 60% of all memory was allocated in CRYPTO_malloc. Unfortunately, the lack of stack frames made it impossible to see where that was being called from.

Running GSI-authenticated condor_q under valgrind shows a leak going back to at least 7.1.4, probably earlier. The leak is in Condor_Auth_X509::get_server_info(), which does not free memory allocated in a couple globus calls that it makes: 

  definitely lost: 616 bytes in 7 blocks
  indirectly lost: 2,054 bytes in 100 blocks

On a platform that supports VOMS (linux), I found another leak reported by valgrind when I run condor_q: 

==3765== 16,736 (552 direct, 16,184 indirect) bytes in 6 blocks are definitely lost in loss record 116 of 122
==3765==    at 0x40213C0: malloc (vg_replace_malloc.c:149)
==3765==    by 0x82D29DD: default_malloc_ex (in /scratch/dan/condor/peep/src/condor_q.V6/condor_q)
==3765==    by 0x82D305E: CRYPTO_malloc (in /scratch/dan/condor/peep/src/condor_q.V6/condor_q)
==3765==    by 0x830D046: asn1_item_ex_combine_new (in /scratch/dan/condor/peep/src/condor_q.V6/condor_q)
==3765==    by 0x830FC5D: ASN1_item_ex_d2i (in /scratch/dan/condor/peep/src/condor_q.V6/condor_q)
==3765==    by 0x8310400: ASN1_item_d2i (in /scratch/dan/condor/peep/src/condor_q.V6/condor_q)
==3765==    by 0x8304A14: ASN1_item_dup (in /scratch/dan/condor/peep/src/condor_q.V6/condor_q)
==3765==    by 0x8307BD6: X509_dup (in /scratch/dan/condor/peep/src/condor_q.V6/condor_q)
==3765==    by 0x8280FF0: globus_gsi_cred_get_cert_chain (globus_gsi_cred_handle.c:996)
==3765==    by 0x815DC09: extract_VOMS_info (globus_utils.c:313)
==3765==    by 0x81FA039: Condor_Auth_X509::authenticate_client_gss(CondorError*) (condor_auth_x509.cpp:742)
==3765==    by 0x81FAA06: Condor_Auth_X509::authenticate(char const*, CondorError*) (condor_auth_x509.cpp:159)
==3765==
==3765== LEAK SUMMARY:
==3765==    definitely lost: 552 bytes in 6 blocks.
==3765==    indirectly lost: 16,184 bytes in 690 blocks.

I have confirmed that the daemon-side of the connection has the same leak. This leak goes away if I set USE_VOMS_ATTRIBUTES = False. The globus function globus_gsi_cred_get_cert_chain appears to be the cause of the leak, even though we are calling sk_x509_free on the allocated object. I found that calling sk_x509_pop_free() instead of sk_x509_free() solves the leak. This is consistent with other uses of globus_gsi_cred_get_cert_chain() in condor code.
